title: Roadside Attractions
name: Roadside Attractions
description:
A Map by Jason

Funny and amazing distractions that you can't pass up while driving around anywhere.

properties.name: Bad Karma newsbox
properties.description: Posted by Jason a converted oregonian newsbox claiming you\'ll be cursed if you bypass the (totally nonfunctioning) security system (broken lock) and look inside. contents may change, but i found a tri-met transit map among the rubbish, crunched up week old papers, milk carton, and dirty sock.

properties.name: Boeing 727 Conversion Home
properties.description: Posted by Jake   Mid Stage conversion of a retired plane into an 1100 square foot home. Tours given, Hilarious Website http://www.airplanehome.com/

properties.name: Cenote Dzitnup - Lake in a cave
properties.description: Posted by Jason between Tulum and Coba, MexicoSomewhat creepy underground lake with natural spotlight and tons of stalagtites. Local girls swimming in gowns, villagers selling crafts, young boys offering to watch your car for you.

properties.name: Dinosaur Park
properties.description: Posted by Phototron   Granger, WAA park just of highway 82 in Granger Washington. This park has a lot of painted concrete dinosaurs.

properties.name: Great Ideas
properties.description: Posted by TravelersE. Burnside st. Portland, OregonI was walking towards downtown Portland today along Burnside. I came across this sign. Man, I never knew it was this easy. That\'s fucking great.

properties.name: Growling Chupacabra vs Screaming Raccoon
properties.description: Posted by Jason NE 20th & sumner, portland, orOK, this is serious! Walking around along Sumner St last night, around 11 or 12, listening to a podcast. I hear such a loud screaming sound that I take off my headphones and am standing directly in front of the tree pictured here. Some kind of feral brutality was going down. One growling, snorting, snarling, deep, nightmarishly terrifying beast could be heard high up in the tree shaking around a terrified, squealing, shrieking, screaming animal for a duration of no less than 2 minutes. Neighborhood dogs started barking at the noise, but no humans came to investigate. Then what had previously only been auditory exposure, changed. I saw the branches at the very top of this tree bend out, and the treetop began to shake violently. At first I thought the aggressor must be a raccoon, but the size of the disruption was more along the lines of what you\'d expect from something almost human in scale. It was huge, it was wild. Then the screaming stopped. Then I heard the monster descending very rapidly within the branches of this very tall tree, and started to consider what would happen if a bloody predator, of any size, came barging over the fence and towards me. The dogs were still barking. I noticed there were a lot of dogs, behind a lot of tall fences. In fact every house on the block was actively protecting itself from the threat of invasion. Could this monster be a known phenomena? Known yet suppressed? After all, not a single person came to see what the noise was, what all the noise was about. Had they learned their lesson the hard way? Should this beast be ignored? Should I not have stopped?

properties.name: Overgrown Truck
properties.description: Posted by Jason

properties.name: The Corn Palace
properties.description: Posted by Oleander601 N. Main St., Mitchell, SDThe corn palace is created and destroyed every year. It\'s a building decorated with corn. It\'s fascinating to see, never mind the tourist-trap keychain and cedar box \'gift\' shops that seem to go with every tourist attraction in the country. The amazin part is on the outside, the run-the-people-through-like-sheep run of the mill story-of-the-palace tour is on the inside. The outside is worth the trip, the inside is...well...eh.

properties.name: The Elvis Still Lives Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Oleander A building with 2 large ars outfront that were once owned by Elvis. Inside this (small) structure, half of the place is dedicated to authentic items owned by Elvis (read: a baby carriage his mother used to put him into), a recreation of Elvis\'s grave, a HUGE document proving that Elvis was employed by the CIA, and similar things. Crammed into the spaces where museuam-like items are not displayed are all of the mugs, keychains, cedar boxes, t-shirts, and wallclocks a person could possibly want. The other half of the building has food. Giant canisters of canned peaches and similar things of interest to person\'s stocking a bomb shelter or preparing a secured area just in case the government decided to tresspass on their land... Note: the location is an approximation - it\'s somewhere between Columbia MO and St. Louis MO on 70.

properties.name: The Mystery Spot
properties.description: Posted by Jason465 Mystery Spot Rd, santa cruz, caThe Mystery Spot is an area about 150 feet in diameter located in the redwood forests just outside of Santa Cruz, California. Within the Mystery Spot you will be baffled as the laws of physics and gravity cease to exist. Discovered in 1939 and opened to the public in 1940, the Mystery Spot has amazed and perplexed hundreds of thousands of visitors from all over the world. Many return again to experience the puzzling variations in gravity, perspective, height and more. Theories: Flying saucer fans speculate that cones of metal were secretly brought here and buried in our earth as guidance systems for their spacecraft. Other theories about what causes the Mystery Spot include carbon dioxide seeping out of the earth, the “highest dielectric biocosmic radiation” known anywhere in the world, and radiesthesia... whatever the cause is, it remains a mystery.

properties.name: The Republic of Cascadia
properties.description: Posted by ParkerburnmillVancouver will be the capitol of Cascadia. sorry G... John McLoughin "The Father of Oregon" - Van-cruiser. 3-6-0 nucka Oregon Trail has two endings. If you go over the land route you end in Oregon City if you shoot the cascades you end in Fort Vancouver. Both endings have the same pic of Mt. Hood! Vancouver Wa. would have to be the capitol of Cascadia for many different reasons. a) we would have to establish a new graffic standard in architecture. We require vast open spaces that are accessable to the populace. This new spectacle should have some sort of historic barometer to bolster the foundation of the Cascadian icon. Vancouver is by no doubt the center of metropolitan growth from Yeurba Buena (San Fransisco/Oakland) to Vancouver Island. b) We have to acknowledge the power of the Columbia. It is the source of our economic fortitude. Deep ports, Hydroelectricity and nature conservation would all be priority issues and should be give the respect that only Vancouver is able to exemplify. c)Vancouver is a symbolic military post. Marshall and Roosevelt drafted the Pacific Theatre of Operations from Vancouver. Some argue that the Army AirForce was sharpened as a tactical weapon at Peirson Airport. When the Russians came west on the first transpolar flight they landed in Vancouver. The Kaiser Liberty ships were built on this side of the river. d) even the beer industry was started by the Nor\'Westers and Hudson\'s Bay employees (Vancouver) e) We got the Ross Complex and the rest of the BPA infrastructure. Trojan is in Oregon. The capitol is not as interesting as taking all the fissionable and radioactive material in the region and loading it onto freight trains. Drive it up past the continental divide and unhook the box cars. They moved the reactor but the spent fuel rods are on your side of the River. Cascadia would portion resources for the construction of monoliths and architectural nuevo. Avante garde physical environments and organic preservation that is considerably more harmonious than the current thread of thought. Ban GMO\'s, redesign hydroelectric harvesting, upgrade and prolong the life span of infrastructure, build a high speed train from Alaska to San Fransisco, erect skyscrapers that lay down into draw bridges, suspend domes over neighborhoods. Sponsor safe, efficient and profitable space tourism. Build swimming pools with four story water slides in everyones backyard. Frostitute and I were both born in Portland and our roots are Oregon in origin. We both grew up in the \'couv and King county. I can\'t say Washington is better, we have our problems. Oregon is wild and less dense. Washington has higher altitudes and a greater propensity for volcanic eradication. Oregon has- Full liqour, full nudity, and gambling in the same room. The right to die. Sk8 Parks (the best in the world) Washington has- Puget Sound Killer Whales D.B. Cooper

properties.name: World's Smallest Park moving for 6 months.
properties.description: Posted by Jason  SW Naito & Taylor, Portland, ORThe world\'s smallest park - as recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records - is about to move... but only temporarily. Due to road construction, Mill Ends Park (24 inches across and located at the intersection of downtown Portland\'s Southwest Taylor Street and Naito Parkway) will be moved 80 feet from its current location. The park will reside in the plaza area of Portland\'s World Trade Center complex for approximately six months. According to Portland Parks & Recreation officials, a move was necessary to protect the tiny green space from the threat posed by the much larger construction equipment. (What Portlanders won\'t do to protect the environment.) When the Naito Parkway roadway improvements are completed in six or seven months, the park will be moved back to a new location on Naito Parkway, 7.5 feet east of its current home. The big - or little - move takes place on Tuesday, Feb. 7. Some sort of "mobile platform," perhaps an all-terrain vehicle, will be used to move the park in its entirety. Mill Ends Park, which was dedicated as an official city park in 1976, is one of 200 parks managed by Portland Parks & Recreation. Note: At this time, the city has no plans to move Portland\'s 5,000-acre Forest Park.

properties.name: sidewalk fossils of fallen leaves
properties.description: Posted by Jason nw 23rd near marshall st, portland, orapparently laid in the autumn, this sidewalk patch is decorated with an amazing plethora of nearly pristine oak and maple leaf fossils.
